awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Memory Bookmarking: An Approach to Improve Recall in Surveys
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance survey methods for time-use measurement.  Social scientists widely use retrospective survey questions (questions about events that occurred in the past) to gather information about respondents' recent autobiographical events. Recall of even recent events is burdensome for respondents, however, and it often leads to uneven data quality due to recall error. This project will experimentally evaluate a new approach called Memory Bookmarking (MB) to address recall error in surveys. The MB approach collects information about respondents' experiences while they are underway. This information is later fed back to respondents as memory cues or bookmarks. Depending on the experimental condition, respondents will be asked to provide bookmarks about everyday events, in the form of text messages, photographs, or locations. The approach should not only improve memory for the cued events but also help respondents remember other events that are temporally adjacent and semantically related to the cued event -- much like an actual bookmark allows readers to see what is on the previous and next pages. The results of this project will advance current thinking about autobiographical memory, especially about the formats (verbal, visual, and spatial) in which people primarily represent the events of their lives. The project will use techniques from data science to analyze unstructured data and thus contribute to ongoing efforts to integrate data science techniques into survey methodology. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, support is provided to enable a promising student to establish a strong, independent research career.

The MB approach will be evaluated in a factorial experiment in which respondents are asked to reconstruct the full sequence of events they have experienced over the prior forty-eight hours.  MB respondents are "pinged" on their smartphone at designated times and asked to provide information via their smartphones about the event that is in progress at that moment. This information is then presented to the respondents as memory cues to help them reconstruct all their activities, not just the pinged events, during the prior forty-eight hours. Respondents' recall will be compared between the experimental conditions created by crossing the number of pings with the bookmark formats, and between the bookmark conditions and a no-bookmark control condition. The research will address the following questions: Does the MB approach lead to more accurate and complete recall than when no cues are provided? How effective are the three formats of memory cues (verbal, visual, and spatial) for different types of events?  Will respondents reply to pings in a timely manner during the forty-eight hours, especially as the number of bookmarks increases?

por.por_cntn:
This study proposed and implemented a new data collection methodology ?Memory Bookmarking (MB)?, which is able to collect real-time multimodal data via text messages (textual, photographic and geographical data) as well as to preload the real-time data as memory cues in a customized time diary instrument. As an outcome, a new data collection system which implements the MB approach was built during this project.

Overall 2050 volunteers signed up for and completed our study. They were recruited from several online sources (e.g., Amazon Mechanical Turk, Craiglist) and staff directories from two universities. Every completer gets $10 Amazon gift code as their reward. The overall participation rate is relatively high (74.3%), which demonstrates the feasibility of using such approach in real survey data collection.

The MB approach was evaluated in a factorial experiment. Every participant completed a first time diary by recalling what they have done in the past 24 hours as a baseline diary. Upon their completion, our system randomly assigns them to one of the five experimental conditions given their demographic stratum (e.g., gender, age, education etc.) and schedules a second time diary in the following week. The five experimental conditions include a control group and 4 cue groups. Participants in the cue groups were randomly signaled 4 times during the scheduled day to record up to 4 memory cues. We varied the type of cues ? the type of real-time data extracted from their smartphones ? in the cue groups: textual description of what they were doing when they were signaled; textual description of what they were doing and how they were feeling when signaled; a photo indicating what they were doing or the current surroundings when signaled; a GPS location when signaled. The cues were collected and preloaded into the time diary so that these respondents were asked to complete the second time diary in which four time slots contain either a textual description, a photograph, or a geolocation, i.e., location on a map.

We compared the data quality and respondent burden among the five groups. In summary, we found some evidence that respondents recall and report more fine-grained events which occurred at the cued times when cues are present. This phenomenon might be stronger if the cues are textual descriptions or photos but less strong if the cues are maps. We didn?t find clear evidence to support that presenting cues would promote better data quality of the entire time diary as a whole based on objective measures, although some evidence shows that subjectively respondents thought that cues were helpful and that they answered the time diary differently when cues were present. In terms of respondent burden, we found that respondents didn?t think that replying to a few messages (<= 6 messages) required an unreasonable amount of work, especially when all text messages only required clicking on a link to provide their GPS locations.

The results of the study show the potential of using the MB approach or using information collected from smartphones as cues to probe further information directly related to the cues. This can be applied to data collection relating to human's everyday behavior. Instead of asking people to recall their behaviors, such as drinking, drug use, dietary intake, transportation, and social interactions after the fact, it is possible to collect information actively (e.g., texts or photos) or passively (e.g., GPS information) along the way and use this information to probe them or cue them for further information.

The mixed results for the time diary application left more questions than answers. If respondents said cues were helpful but actually reported fewer events overall when cued than not cued (which was the case), what would we change to make the task easier and the cues more salient and useful? We could for example, give respondents the freedom to choose the way they reconstruct their day when filling out the diary; or we could have the cues always afloat on the diary page to remind them of the cues; or we could increase the number of cues, especially when the effort to generate them is minimal (e.g., GPS cues) and use a sufficient amount of cues in the time diary to make every event a cued event. These modifications of this method could have great potential for time diary collectors and users.
